repnme.cdata!:
Moldova - Second Structural Adjustment
            Loan/Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project was
            satisfactory, with a likely sustainability, but with modest
            institutional development impact. Lessons convey that the
            Bank could have taken a more realistic approach regarding
            the level of adjustment Moldova was being forced to make in
            restoring economic growth, by addressing longer-term, and
            deeper-structural adjustments in the definition of project
            objectives. Hence, the agreed measures led to significant
            reduction of program effectiveness, conducive to extended
            implementation delays. Instead, front-loading conditionality
            prior to Board presentation, or the use of single tranche
            operations, could have been useful tools under circumstances
            of intense resource constraints, as is the case of Moldova.
            Furthermore, the inability to coordinate foreign assistance,
            should be guided by the Bank's assistance in donor
            coordination. Regardless of success, the privatization
            program as a whole, was not sufficiently deep, neither was
            the agricultural privatization - which seemingly, only
            provided a means of subsistence to the rural population.
            Therefore it is worth considering the privatization process
            early on, focused on post-privatization market development
            for agriculture, and, on the need for strong political will
            regarding industrial privatization.

            LOAN TO MOLDOVA,TF027121-PHRD-SECOND STRUCTURAL

repnme.cdata!:
Moldova - Second Structural Adjustment Loan
            and Structural Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Structural Adjustment Loan
            and Credit Project (SAL II) will support the
            Government's reforms necessary to create conditions for
            a resumption of growth and improvement in living conditions
            in Moldova. To achieve this objective, critical reforms need
            to be undertaken in: i) improving financial discipline; ii)
            privatizing the energy sector; iii) accelerating land reform
            and privatization; iv) reforming the pension system; and v)
            completing enterprise privatization, specially for
            small-scale enterprises. SAL II will have three fundamental
            benefits. First, the reform program supported by the SAL II
            will address key bottlenecks, and enhance the prospects of
            long-term growth and improved living standards by setting in
            place a comprehensive program of reforms that will span the
            1998 Parliamentary elections. Second, it will provide
            short-term budgetary support essential for maintaining the
            level of basic public services. The availability of low
            cost, non-inflationary budgetary financing will help
            consolidate Moldova's economic stabilization. Third, it
            will provide necessary foreign exchange to purchase imports
            critical for Moldova's economic activity while
            maintaining creditworthiness. Finally, measures supported by
            SAL II --payments discipline and completion of privatization
            and land reform-- are necessary conditions for sustainable
            growth and creditworthiness.
